articles.headline: Furor Over U.S. Steel Bid Puts Secretive Government Panel In Spotlight
articles.snippet: Backlash over the deal has echoes of the 1980s when Nippon Steel tried and failed to buy another American metal company.
articles.abstract: Backlash over the deal has echoes of the 1980s when Nippon Steel tried and failed to buy another American metal company.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a campaign event last month in Pennsylvania, the heartland of American steel manufacturing, President Biden made clear that he does not want the proposed takeover of U.S. Steel by Japan’s Nippon Steel to happen.

articles.headline: Henry Cuellar Indicted Over Bribery Scheme
articles.snippet: Mr. Cuellar and his wife are accused of accepting bribes from a bank in Mexico City and an oil and gas company owned by Azerbaijan. He has maintained they are innocent.
articles.abstract: Mr. Cuellar and his wife are accused of accepting bribes from a bank in Mexico City and an oil and gas company owned by Azerbaijan. He has maintained they are innocent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Representative Henry Cuellar, a Texas Democrat in a crucial swing district, and his wife were charged with participating in a yearslong $600,000 bribery scheme involving Azerbaijan and a Mexican bank, according to a federal indictment unsealed in Houston on Friday.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Luke Broadwater

articles.headline: Family Values or Fighting Valor? Russia Grapples With Women’s Wartime Role.
articles.snippet: Russian military efforts to recruit women from prisons and civilian life have clashed with President Vladimir V. Putin’s conservative agenda.
articles.abstract: Russian military efforts to recruit women from prisons and civilian life have clashed with President Vladimir V. Putin’s conservative agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Russian Army is gradually expanding the role of women as it seeks to balance President Vladimir V. Putin’s promotion of traditional family roles with the need for new recruits for the war in Ukraine.
articles.byline: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ekaterina Bodyagina

articles.headline: Got an Idea for a Toy? Toymakers Want to Hear From You.
articles.snippet: Companies like Lego and Mattel have divisions that seek out design concepts directly from collectors and other highly dedicated fan bases.
articles.abstract: Companies like Lego and Mattel have divisions that seek out design concepts directly from collectors and other highly dedicated fan bases.
articles.lead_paragraph: Near the end of 2022, Lucas Bolt, an environmental artist and Lego enthusiast in Amsterdam, was working on a design for a Lego set the company had crowdsourced to commemorate the 50th anniversary of Dungeons & Dragons, the tabletop role-playing game.

articles.headline: Here Come a Trillion Cicadas. The Midwest Is Abuzz.
articles.snippet: Illinois is the center of the cicada emergence that is on the way. Two groups of cicadas are expected at once, leaving some people queasy, others thrilled.
articles.abstract: Illinois is the center of the cicada emergence that is on the way. Two groups of cicadas are expected at once, leaving some people queasy, others thrilled.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the third graders of Cumberland Elementary in the Chicago suburbs colored, clipped and glued paper to make cicadas with filmy wings, they confided their fears about what is about to happen in Illinois.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Jamie Kelter Davis

articles.headline: How Scammers Are Stealing Food Stamps From Struggling Americans
articles.snippet: Thieves are using skimmers to drain millions in food stamps and other public benefits from the neediest Americans.
articles.abstract: Thieves are using skimmers to drain millions in food stamps and other public benefits from the neediest Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Something was very wrong with Jackie Kirks’s food stamp card.

articles.headline: From Free Speech to Free Palestine: Six Decades of Student Protest
articles.snippet: The protests against Israel’s war in Gaza are merely the latest in a tradition of student-led, left-leaning activism dating back at least to the civil rights and anti-Vietnam War protests of the 1960s.
articles.abstract: The protests against Israel’s war in Gaza are merely the latest in a tradition of student-led, left-leaning activism dating back at least to the civil rights and anti-Vietnam War protests of the 1960s.
articles.lead_paragraph: An American college student looked out at a sea of protesters and spoke of a machine that had grown so “odious” that it had left people of good will little choice. There must be protest.

articles.headline: Tesla Pullback Puts Onus on Others to Build Electric Vehicle Chargers
articles.snippet: The automaker led by Elon Musk is no longer planning to take the lead in expanding the number of places to fuel electric vehicles. It’s not clear how quickly other companies will fill the gap.
articles.abstract: The automaker led by Elon Musk is no longer planning to take the lead in expanding the number of places to fuel electric vehicles. It’s not clear how quickly other companies will fill the gap.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla, blindsided competitors, suppliers and his own employees this week by reversing course on his aggressive push to build electric vehicle chargers in the United States, a major priority of the Biden administration.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Ivan Penn

articles.headline: Jerry Seinfeld Can No Longer Be About Nothing
articles.snippet: The comedian, long beloved for his apolitical riffs, has been wrestling with what it means to be Jewish amid the Israel-Hamas war. Not everyone is pleased.
articles.abstract: The comedian, long beloved for his apolitical riffs, has been wrestling with what it means to be Jewish amid the Israel-Hamas war. Not everyone is pleased.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jerry Seinfeld became a mic-cradling, cereal-eating, “did-you-ever-notice”-ing avatar of American Jewish life with a brazenly shrugging persona: a merry indifference to weighty material as a comedian and in his megahit TV show about nothing, as petty and apolitical as he seemed to be.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer and Marc Tracy

articles.headline: China Is Buying Gold Like There’s No Tomorrow
articles.snippet: The global price of gold has reached its highest levels as Chinese investors and consumers, wary of real estate and stocks, buy the metal at a record pace.
articles.abstract: The global price of gold has reached its highest levels as Chinese investors and consumers, wary of real estate and stocks, buy the metal at a record pace.
articles.lead_paragraph: As gold surged this year to its highest price ever, Xena Lin joined the frenzy by making monthly purchases of gold “beans,” pebble-like morsels of the precious metal.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu

articles.headline: Just How Dangerous Is Europe’s Rising Far Right?
articles.snippet: Anti-immigration parties with fascist roots — and an uncertain commitment to democracy — are now mainstream.
articles.abstract: Anti-immigration parties with fascist roots — and an uncertain commitment to democracy — are now mainstream.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jordan Bardella, 28, is the new face of the far right in France. Measured, clean-cut and raised in the hardscrabble northern suburbs of Paris, he laces his speeches with references to Victor Hugo and believes that “no country succeeds by denying or being ashamed of itself.”

articles.headline: When Prison and Mental Illness Amount to a Death Sentence
articles.snippet: The downward spiral of one inmate, Markus Johnson, shows the larger failures of the nation’s prisons to care for the mentally ill.
articles.abstract: The downward spiral of one inmate, Markus Johnson, shows the larger failures of the nation’s prisons to care for the mentally ill.
articles.lead_paragraph: Markus Johnson slumped naked against the wall of his cell, skin flecked with pepper spray, his face a mask of puzzlement, exhaustion and resignation. Four men in black tactical gear pinned him, his face to the concrete, to cuff his hands behind his back.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Carlos Javier Ortiz

articles.headline: A FAFSA Fiasco Has Students Still Asking: Which College Can They Afford?
articles.snippet: The new application for federal tuition aid was meant to be simpler. High school seniors say it has been anything but, and some are still unsure of their plans after graduation.
articles.abstract: The new application for federal tuition aid was meant to be simpler. High school seniors say it has been anything but, and some are still unsure of their plans after graduation.
articles.lead_paragraph: By this time of year, college-bound high school seniors are usually celebrating their choices, researching dorms and even thinking of their majors. This year, that’s not necessarily the case.
articles.byline: By Colbi Edmonds and Bernard Mokam

articles.headline: How One Latino Pastor Became a Foot Soldier for Trump
articles.snippet: Republicans have spent years drawing Latino evangelicals into their fold. At one growing church in the Las Vegas suburbs, Donald J. Trump is reaping the benefits.
articles.abstract: Republicans have spent years drawing Latino evangelicals into their fold. At one growing church in the Las Vegas suburbs, Donald J. Trump is reaping the benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent Tuesday evening, two teenage boys approached their pastor, Camilo Perez, before Bible study. They wanted his take on a debate that had been gnawing at them. Their friends from a local public high school had been talking about discrimination against Latinos. Did the pastor agree? Does the government give white people more power?
articles.byline: By Jennifer Medina and Isadora Kosofsky

articles.headline: Gallows Humor and Talk of Escape: Trump’s Possible Return Rattles Capital
articles.snippet: At Washington dinner parties, dark jokes abound about where to go into exile if the former president reclaims the White House.
articles.abstract: At Washington dinner parties, dark jokes abound about where to go into exile if the former president reclaims the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has become the topic of the season at Washington dinner parties and receptions. Where would you go if it really happens?

articles.headline: ‘The Fall Guy’ Fizzles With $28 Million in Ticket Sales
articles.snippet: While enough for No. 1, the big-budget original movie gave Hollywood its lowest start to its summer box office season since 1995.
articles.abstract: While enough for No. 1, the big-budget original movie gave Hollywood its lowest start to its summer box office season since 1995.
articles.lead_paragraph: “The Fall Guy” seemed to have everything.

articles.headline: Tensions Rise in Silicon Valley Over Sales of Start-Up Stocks
articles.snippet: The market for shares of hot start-ups like SpaceX and Stripe is projected to reach a record $64 billion this year.
articles.abstract: The market for shares of hot start-ups like SpaceX and Stripe is projected to reach a record $64 billion this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sohail Prasad, an entrepreneur, launched a fund in March called the Destiny Tech100. The fund owns shares in hot tech start-ups like the payments firm Stripe, the rocket maker SpaceX and the artificial intelligence company OpenAI.

articles.headline: Russia to Hold Drills on Tactical Nuclear Weapons in New Tensions With West
articles.snippet: Russian officials claimed the order was in response to comments from the West about the possibility of more direct involvement in Ukraine. NATO called Russia’s announcement “irresponsible.”
articles.abstract: Russian officials claimed the order was in response to comments from the West about the possibility of more direct involvement in Ukraine. NATO called Russia’s announcement “irresponsible.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Russia said on Monday that it would hold military exercises with troops based near Ukraine to practice for the possible use of battlefield nuclear weapons, a provocative warning aimed at discouraging the West from deepening its support for Ukraine.
